ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RESERVISTS IN-CAMP TRAINING
(Deferment)


    1. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (a) how many reservists requested for deferment of their in-camp training in 1984, 1985 and 1986; (b) how many of these requests were approved in each of the three years; and (c) what are the criteria for granting the deferment.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Services) (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the statistics which have been requested are given in this Table which I am handing out now. [Copies of Table (Cols. 1141 - 1142) distributed to hon. Members.]
Table - RESERVISTS IN-CAMP TRAINING DEFERMENT CASES 1984-1986 (Cols. 1141 - 1142)


    Mindef does not encourage reservists to apply for deferment, especially when their units are scheduled for overseas training. Reserve units must train together as one cohesive group to build up teamwork and esprit de corps. The absence of one critical reservist during in-camp training does not only affect the training of that reservist himself but it reduces the value of the in-camp training for every other member of the unit whose time will be wasted, as they will be unable to train properly as one unit for their operational role in war. Reservists are given six to 12 months of advance notice for in-camp training so that both they and their employers can have ample time to adjust their work plans and so minimize the need for deferment.

    Mindef has delegated the authority to grant deferments to reservist unit commanders. Many of these commanders are themselves reservists and have a close feel for reservists and their problems. The commanders decide on the basis of the merits of the application and on the urgency of the training requirement. In cases where reservists are pursuing full-time courses in institutions of higher learning or where there are compassionate reasons, like parents or children who are critically ill, their applications are usually approved. If the commander turns down the deferment application, the

Column: 1028

reservist may appeal to Mindef. Appeals are examined case by case, taking into account both the plight of the reservist and the requirements of the units. The statistics of appeals and approvals of appeals have also been included in the Table.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, may I ask of the Hon. Minister, if the reservist is the only son of the family and upon whom the family business depends very much, would his request for deferment be specially considered if the period or time to him is not suitable for him to leave his business?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, we will consider the matter sympathetically. But it is not possible to approve deferment on the basis that the reservist is the only son, because he is likely to remain an only son for many years to come. You cannot have a deferment every year until your younger brother grows up.

HDB FLATS
(Price Increase)


    2. Mr Chew Heng Ching asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board has any plan to increase the prices of flats in 1987.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Deputy Speaker, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, there is no plan to increase the base price of HDB flats this year. But a more rational pricing system that will better reflect the differences in market values of flats because of immediate surroundings, height, view and orientation is under consideration. If such a system is found feasible, it will be implemented in stages.

HDB RENTAL FLATS
(Waiting list)


    3. Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many applicants are on the

Column: 1029

waiting list for one-, two- and three-room Housing and Development Board rental apartments; (b) what is the estimated waiting time for new applicants for two- and three-room rental apartments; and (c) whether the HDB will consider converting some of the vacant two- and three-room sale apartments to rental apartments to help expedite the allocation of rental apartments.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, as at 28th February 1987, there were 3,014 applicants on the waiting list to rent 1- and 2-room flats (976 of which were for 1-room flats and 2,038 applicants for 2-room flats). There are no applicants on the waiting list to rent 3-room flats as HDB has stopped registering such applications.

    Sir, only 5,960 units of vacant flats are available for letting. These flats are also required for tenants affected by relocation from existing 1- and 2-room rental flats. Therefore, public applicants have to wait for 2 1/2 to three years for allocation of a rental flat.

    The HDB no longer builds 2-room flats for sale under the Home Ownership Scheme because of lack of demand. The available 3-room vacant flats were built for sale in line with the Government's objective to promote full Home Ownership. Converting the 3-room home ownership flats for rental would be inconsistent with this policy. Furthermore, the monthly instalment of $142 for 20 years for a 3-room flat is comparable to the rental of a 3-room flat at $110 for a 3-room simplified flat, and not many people would want to rent such 3-room flats. Sir, there is no plan to convert these sale flats for rental.

NOISE AND AIR POLLUTION FROM MRT SYSTEM
(Measures to control)


    The following Question stood in the name of Dr Koh Lam Son:

    5. To ask the Minister for the Environment what measures are being taken to control noise and air pollution from the Mass Rapid Transit System.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Dr Koh Lam Son.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching: Question No. 5, Sir.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, at the outset of the Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) project in June 1983, my Ministry had recommended noise guidelines to MRTC for their trains and mechanical/ventilation equipment. MRTC have also taken every care in the design of their tracks and the specifications for their equipment to keep noise levels to a minimum. They have with them the services of noise consultants to further advise them on these matters.

Column: 1031



    Sir, the viaduct which supports the tracks is made of concrete with high mass and damping characteristics to minimize noise that may be induced by vibrations from passing trains. The trains will run on continuously welded rails to minimize noise that would otherwise have been caused by the wheels running over gaps in between sections of the rail. In addition, these rails rest on ballasted trackbeds for better absorption of vibrations. At critical underground sections near to high-rise buildings, special floating slabs on the trackwork will cut down the transmission of vibration and noise to the superstructures above. These measures have been taken to ensure that the MRT is constructed with good noise control features from the start.

    The noise levels of the trains have yet to be tested in actual operations. Noise measurements will be carried out when the MRT is in operation. In the last eventuality, Sir, provisions have been made on the elevated sections of the MRT line to affix noise barriers at critical sections should noise prove to be still a problem.

    Sir, as the MRT trains run on electricity, no air pollution from the running of these trains is anticipated.

     Dr Ang Kok Peng (Buona Vista): Sir, when the MRT is in operation, the Ministry will be monitoring the noise level. What I want to know is what will the Ministry be monitoring - the traffic noise index or the noise pollution level, or what?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, neither. We will just be measuring the sound level in dbA, or what we call the A-weighted sound level. Only for specialized studies do we measure the traffic noise index or the noise pollution level which the Member for Buona Vista has mentioned. Sir, it has been demonstrated that the A- weighted sound level correlates just as well with the other ratings, as far as subjective response is concerned. And because of its simplicity, it has been recommended for use in building codes, anti-noise ordinances and monitoring of urban traffic noise.

COMMUNITY CENTRE IN HOUGANG AVENUE 8 OR 10


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Community Development whether the People's Association has any plans to build a temporary community centre in the neighbourhood of Hougang Avenue 8 or 10; and whether it plans to build a modern community centre in Hougang New Town.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am replying in my capacity as Deputy Chairman of the People's Association.

    Hougang New Town will have about 30,000 dwelling units when it is fully developed by 1990. Based on the population catchment approach approved by the Government for building community centres, the New Town will need three modern community centres, each to serve about 10,000 families living within its vicinity. There are already two modern community centres located within Hougang New Town. These are the Paya Lebar Community Centre at Surin Avenue and the Punggol Community Centre at

Column: 1033

Hougang Avenue 3. The People's Association is considering building a third modern community centre in the neighbourhood of Hougang Avenue 8 or 10.

    The PA will discuss further with the Member for Punggol, his community leaders and the HDB regarding the proposed community centre. As it will take several years to plan and build the centre, it may be necessary to set up a temporary centre in the vicinity, preferably to be housed in shophouse units which can be returned to the HDB once the modern centre has been built.

HEPATITIS B IMMUNIZATION


    8. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Acting Minister for Health whether his Ministry will carry out an exercise to vaccinate Singaporeans against Hepatitis B and if he will make it a requirement for all new-born babies to be vaccinated against the disease.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, the Ministry of Health has, since 1983, been immunizing specific groups of Singaporeans who have a high risk of contracting Hepatitis B. They include health care workers, National Servicemen and newborn babies of Hepatitis B- carrier mothers.

    In addition, immunization for a fee for the public was offered at nine Primary Health polyclinics and five Government hospitals from 1985.

    Immunizing all newborn babies against Hepatitis B would be an effective strategy to break the Hepatitis B infection cycle over the long term. My Ministry is currently looking into the implications of making this compulsory for all newborn babies.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee: Sir, may I ask the Hon. Acting Minister, firstly, whether his Ministry would bear the cost of such vaccination and, secondly, if the cost has to be borne by the people, how could this be made cheap and affordable for the people to be immunized against such disease?

Column: 1034



     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, it is precisely because the cost of the vaccine is very high that the Ministry is looking into the implications of making it compulsory. The vaccination is now being made available to the public. For newborn babies, the cost of three doses of vaccination would come to about $60. For adults, the cost of a cycle of three doses would come to $120. This is very much cheaper than what is offered in the private sector. In fact, for adults, it is offered at the cost of the vaccine itself.

VACANT LANDS AT PASIR PANJANG ROAD/ALEXANDRA TERRACE
(Development plans)


    9. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for National Development whether there are plans to develop (i) the vacant land between Alexandra Terrace and Alexandra Lane and (ii) the piece of land (from Perak House) next to the Pasir Panjang Community Centre.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, the land at Alexandra Terrace and Alexandra Lane was acquired for the development of the Port of Singapore Authority.

    The former Perak House next to the Pasir Panjang Community Centre has been relocated to the former Radin Mas School. The vacated building has since been demolished and the land is in State ownership. There are no plans for development at present.

Column: 1034

MARINA SOUTH
(Development plans)


    10. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for National Development what are the short- and long-term proposals for the development of Marina South.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the long-term plan for Marina South envisages the expansion of the

Column: 1035

commercial core at Shenton Way and Raffles Place into Marina South to form an enlarged downtown area. The area north of the East Coast Parkway has therefore been earmarked for commercial use. The area south of the expressway will have a mix of commercial and residential uses. There will be a major park and a coastal promenade for leisure and recreational activities. An area near the major park has been earmarked as an institutional zone for civic and cultural developments.

    Two MRT stations will serve Marina South in the area where commercial developments are planned.

    In the interim, the area south of the expressway will be developed for leisure and recreational activities. URA has recently sold 11 parcels of land totalling 7.3 hectares for the development of recreational and food facilities. Adjacent to these parcels, the Parks and Recreation Department will develop a public park. These developments are targeted for completion by 1989.

ATTACK ON THE PRESS BY THE MEMBER FOR POTONG PASIR
(Statement by the Minister for Communications and Information)


     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, as Standing Orders would only permit me to make a statement in the morning, I will make it this morning even though the Member for Potong Pasir is yet again slow in taking up his seat and is not here.

    Sir, yesterday, I rose to tender a transcript of the Member's speech given on Monday to provide him with the exact words which he asked for on Monday.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: All right.

morning to give the Member the opportunity to respond.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): I have to make it very clear that I have no intention whatsoever to defame anyone, including local journalists. Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I have made a mistake in citing a local senior journalist in this House on 23rd March and I would now like to apologize to him.

     Some hon. Members: Hear, hear!

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am happy to note that in rising to protect the interest of all Singaporeans against MPs who make scurrilous remarks about them, I have managed to get the Member for Potong Pasir to withdraw his statement and to apologize to the journalist concerned.

    Sir, this is important. The purpose of it all is not to challenge any individual Member of Parliament but to protect the interest of the public. On this particular occasion, it is a journalist. On another occasion, it can be an engineer, an accountant, a hawker, a bus driver, anybody, anybody who crosses the path of MPs. They should not be attacked in this House where the member of the public is unable to defend himself.

    Sir, I would also like to bring to the attention of the House the fact that the Member, in his speech on Monday, has also misled the House. The Member told us that the article that he took offence with was headlined, "PAP will win". According to a newspaper report in the Straits Times this morning, an article with such a headline did not exist. The headline was "PAP is confident of win in Anson today". This is totally different from what the Member for Potong Pasir told us the other day.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Chairman, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head V be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead VA-01-1100 of the Main Estimates*.

    In moving this amendment, my committee Members and I are concerned with a number of issues relating to trade and industry. I will mention some of them and my Members will speak on the rest.

    The first issue concerns our bilateral trade relations with different countries. As we all know, we are faced with increasing protectionism today. Last year, we had the case of our exports of tropical fish to the United States banned or restricted for a while. And, from time to time, various items of trade are subjected to scrutiny of various kinds on all kinds of pretexts. This happens not merely in the advanced countries but this happens in developing countries as well. But paradoxically or ironically, within the region of ASEAN, there have been recent moves towards greater economic cooperation or economic integration and there have been no lack of suggestions in this area. At the same time, we have been subjected to harassment, subjected to a lot of non-tariff barriers from various countries in the region. Hon. Members are aware of the existence of exit taxes imposed by some countries in the region. There was a threat to end our airline agreement with Malaysia. Last year, I believe, you, Sir, raised the question of milk powder and water jugs as problems that we have with Malaysia. I believe the water jug problem is still outstanding. And there have also been a number of restrictions on electrical goods which are brought back to Malaysia from Singapore. I understand the list is going to be extended very shortly. What is our Government doing about these measures which have been instituted against us? How can we have greater regional cooperation if our bilateral trade relations are so poor?

    I come now to another issue that has to do with promoting the private sector in

Column: 1038

Singapore as an engine of growth. Sir, we all know that since 1960, our economy has been driven by two economic engines:

    (1) The influx of multi-national corporations coming into Singapore bringing in capital, technology, access to markets, skills and so on; and

    (2) The public sector itself responding to this or in anticipation of the new investments by providing the infrastructure and, of course, our huge public housing programme.

Both of these have spawned a number of other activities in transport, communications, information services and so on and so forth. But we are now at the stage where both of these engines are stalling or are not working as well as they used to. We know, for example, that the net investment commitments in manufacturing have been falling. And public spending on infrastructure and housing is declining and is expected to decline in the years ahead. Our fixed capital formation figures have also been declining in the last two or three years. So we need to have an alternative engine of growth. That means the promotion of services and the stimulation of local enterpreneurship, local enterprises, upgrading them, encouraging them. Government has taken the lead in these two areas. My question to the Minister is: from his monitoring of developments in these areas, is he satisfied and what other measures are necessary?

    Quite recently, General Winston Choo in speaking to the SAF mentioned that a number of soldiers or many soldiers have this kia su spirit. And I believe that this spirit has also infected a lot of other Singaporeans as well, particularly businessmen. It is the fear of failure, the fear of being scolded. It is risk aversion, an attitude of risk aversion. We know the scions or the sons and daughters of many traders and entrepreneurs have now secured jobs in the professions and have become executives and managers. They prefer to do this rather than to become

Column: 1039

entrepreneurs. What can we do to overcome this? The Economic Committee Report had a good analysis of the problems and it was stated there that we should, through the educational process, inculcate a more creative spirit. I hope our independent schools that are going to be set up will be helpful in this regard. But then there may be laws and regulations that we have that may need adjustment. So that is one part of the problem of promoting local entrepreneurship.

    The other part has to do with access to capital. The question is whether we have enough venture capital. I believe it was in 1985 that about $100 million was set aside under the EDB for venture capital. I understand from the Annual Report of EDB that very little actually has been spent. Is EDB the appropriate vehicle, the appropriate institution, to provide this venture capital? Should we not think in terms of a wider network? The problem is this, Sir, that when one goes to a bank for a loan for business or for anything else, one has to produce collateral. If one does not have the collateral, then very small amounts of loan are available on a personal basis, on the basis of your signature, and looking into the background, what kind of job you are doing. This inhibits a lot of businesses from expanding. They may be good entrepreneurs with good ideas, good projects, but they have great difficulty in finding funds for expansion or even for launching their business. Ironically, those companies that may have the collateral end up as colossal failures. We have no lack of examples - Pan-El and other companies that have failed. In other words, banks tend to look at balance sheets rather than to evaluate the character, the personalities of the people coming forward to apply for these loans.

    At the broader level, Sir, I believe we need a very careful investigation of the whole savings, investment, intermediation process. In other words, to study the flow of funds in our economy. Britain has done it. I think there have been two studies. One, the Radcliff Report, and later the Wilson Report. I believe Australia has undertaken such a study too, recently. We need such a study to see how savings get into the hands of investors ultimately. And if there are impediments in the process, then

Column: 1040

these impediments should be removed. There have been no lack of investments in the property market; no lack of investments in financial markets. But we are lacking in investments, in manufacturing, in a lot of service areas that would do Singapore a lot of good.

     Dr Ow Chin Hock (Leng Kee): Mr Chairman, Sir, the first issue I would like to raise is tourism.

    In 1985, the then Minister for Trade and Industry and the current Minister for Finance promised that we would develop Singapore into a major tourist destination in his Ministry's Addendum to the Presidential Address. I asked myself at that time, that looking from the viewpoint of a tourist, what could Singapore offer? We do not have the Great Wall, Taj Mahal, Grand Canyon or River Rhine. We are supposed to be a City in the Exotic East, but some people observed that we have lost the oriental mystique and charm. We are supposed to be an Island in the Sun, yet we have inadequate beach resorts and sea sports facilities. Our world's tallest man-made waterfall in Jurong Bird Park and our third world's largest oil refinery impress no one except economists.

    Hence, I welcome the proposed $1 billion tourism development projects. This package of projects represents the Government's first and major investment in tourism. This project, when completed, will offer a variety of tourist attractions so as to attract more tourists from different regions and different countries and to encourage them to stay longer and spend more. As I understand it, this $1 billion sum is supposed to be seed money. This is to attract the private sector's participation in the development of this tourism project.

    I have three questions here for the Minister.

    (a) What is the expected return on these investments over and above the 16% of foreign exchange earnings at present?

    (b) Apart from F&N participation in the Haw Par Villa project, what are the responses from the private sector so far?

    (c) The Raffles Hotel. This hotel is a unique asset to Singapore. It is an anchor project in the proposed Heritage Link. But

Column: 1041

the upgrading of the hotel, I was told, has encountered some difficulties because the lease period will expire only by the end of 1995 and is under the Rent Control Act. May I ask the Minister what is the present status and when will the restoration work of the hotel begin?

    Apart from developing Singapore as a tourist destination and offering tourist attractions, we must also explore other possibilities:

    (1) Promotion of Singapore as a convention and exhibition centre so as to attract high yield or high value added tourists.

    (2) Cooperation with other Asean countries or other countries like China in promoting tourism.
